author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: A Champion Swimmer Returns, Slowly but Determinedly, to Competition
description: Caeleb Dressel, the seven-time Olympic champion, swam in the nationals after taking a break for mental health reasons. He didn’t win, but he loved everything about being back, even the chlorine.
content: During the eight months Caeleb Dressel spent not swimming, he was surprised by the things he came to miss. Some were simple, like blowing bubbles in the water or the feel of his toes on the grip tape of the starting blocks. But he also missed the chlorine — a swimmer’s nemesis — and the dry skin that comes with hours spent in the pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angel B. Pérez
title: Employers Benefitted from Affirmative Action. It’s Time to Step Up.
description: Colleges can’t do it alone anymore.
content: I’ve been traveling the country speaking to corporate executives about seismic shifts in higher education: a demographic cliff, decreased state funding, ever-rising tuition and a recent poll showing that over half of Americans don’t believe college is worth the cost. And, of course, the Supreme Court’s decision on affirmative action, which was handed down on Thursday, banning the use of race in college admissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch and Christina Goldbaum
title: A Rubik’s Cube, Thick Socks and Giddy Anticipation: The Last Hours of the Titan
description: Five voyagers climbed into the Titan submersible in hopes of joining the select few who have seen the wreck of the Titanic up close. But within hours, their text messages stopped coming.
content: The last time Christine Dawood saw her husband, Shahzada, and their son, Suleman, they were specks on the North Atlantic, bobbing on a floating platform about 400 miles from land. It was Father’s Day, June 18, and she watched from the support ship as they climbed into a 22-foot submersible craft called Titan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: Better Government in New York Depends on Higher Voter Turnout
description: Low turnout may help explain why the actions of elected officials in the city are sometimes bizarrely out of step with the constituents they serve.
content: Preoccupied by daily concerns like paying astronomical sums of rent and deluged by the occasional barrage of apocalyptic wildfire smoke, the average New Yorker clearly wasn’t closely focused on the local primary elections of 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Sales Surge as Tax Credits Fuel Demand
description: Incentives and price cuts made Tesla electric cars cheaper than comparable gasoline models. But the company faces growing competition in China, a key market.
content: Tesla sales rose a better-than-expected 10 percent in the second quarter as the company led by Elon Musk benefited from government incentives and price cuts that made its electric cars less expensive than comparable gasoline models.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: A Weekend of Unrest in France
description: Also, an investigation into the fatal sinking of a migrant ship.
content: France deployed 45,000 police officers across the country overnight Friday and Saturday, as violent riots convulsed multiple cities after the fatal police shooting of a 17-year-old. The government said that about 2,000 people were arrested over two nights of demonstrations, with protesters burning cars, setting fire to buildings and lighting fireworks outside police stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Jack Ewing
title: Lithium Scarcity Pushes Carmakers Into the Mining Business
description: Ford, General Motors and others are striking deals with mining companies to avoid raw material shortages that could thwart their electric vehicle ambitions.
content: Eager to avoid falling further behind Tesla and Chinese car companies, many Western auto executives are bypassing traditional suppliers and committing billions of dollars on deals with lithium mining companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson, Carl Hulse and Alicia Parlapiano
title: House Republicans Demand Deep Cuts to Spending Bills They Rarely Support
description: G.O.P. leaders are tailoring their government funding legislation to far-right lawmakers who are insisting on deep cuts, but who hardly ever vote for spending bills. That’s raising the chances of a fall shutdown.
content: House Republican leaders working to write and pass the spending bills that fund the government face a major hurdle: Their own party — especially their most powerful, arch-conservative faction — has spent the last decade assailing federal spending and, with growing frequency, casting vote after vote against it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Having Initial Success
description: Sam Buchbinder offers moral support.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: A Fatal Shooting and a Hijab Ban: Two Faces of France’s Racial Divisions
description: The almost simultaneous police killing of Nahel Merzouk and a ban on head scarves in soccer were coincidental, but they illuminate France’s crisis of identity and inclusion.
content: Mama Diakité is a French citizen, raised in the suburbs of Paris by two immigrant parents, not far from where a 17-year-old boy was shot by the police during a traffic stop last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Savory Goat Cheese and Dill Dutch Baby Drizzled With Honey and Lemon
description: Yewande Komolafe’s new recipe cooks up in a flash and disappears just as fast.
content: Good morning. Purple finches have come to our bird feeder lately, eating after the cardinals have had their fill and before the red-winged blackbirds arrive. They whomp on the sunflower seeds and I feel as I do when I’ve served something to the children that they particularly like, as if I’ve achieved something, if only by chance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das and Josh Katz
title: Going, Going, Gone? Verstappen Wins Fifth Straight Race.
description: Verstappen extended his winning streak and widened his points lead. Is his third straight Formula 1 title only a matter of time?
content: He might oversleep one Sunday. He might take his Red Bull racecar to the mall and forget where he parked it. Or lose the keys. He might run into the worst run of bad luck in Formula 1 history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: An Elite School, a Boy’s Suicide and a Question of Blame
description: An eighth grader was asked to leave Saint Ann’s, a prestigious private school in Brooklyn. Three months later, he ended his life. Now his parents are suing the school.
content: Ellis Lariviere was an eighth grader at Saint Ann’s, an elite private school in Brooklyn Heights, and he had a lot going for him. Teachers praised him as an “abundantly talented” artist, in a school that trumpeted the arts, and they described him as a positive presence in his classes. He had friends at school and an older brother who was thriving there. Ellis liked to cook for his family, and he imagined himself one day being a professional. He also had dyslexia and an attention deficit disorder, and he struggled to express complex thoughts in writing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Preston
title: Chasing a World Record, They Endured Storms, Sharks and Freak Waves
description: In “Completely Mad,” James Hansen tells the stories of two men who in 1969 vied to be the first to row solo across the Atlantic Ocean.
content: The day before the Apollo mission landed two men on the moon, a British man named John Fairfax waded into Hollywood Beach, Fla., greeted by masses of cheering fans, having been the first person to row solo across the Atlantic Ocean. Eight days later, another Briton, Tom McClean, pulled his dory up a deserted beach in Blacksod Bay, Ireland, having rowed solo across the Atlantic in the opposite direction. While Fairfax was acclaimed and feted, McClean walked to the closest pub, alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: At the Sonic Sphere, a ‘Whoa’ Moment (and Some Music)
description: A hanging concert hall at the Shed in Manhattan purports to offer something “experimental, experiential and communal.” Our critic climbs the stairs.
content: “Whoa,” a man near me said as the curtains swept open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Andy Murray Returns to Wimbledon Aiming for Another Long Run
description: A decade ago, Murray broke the 77-year singles championship drought for British men at Wimbledon. It has been up and down since. Can he recapture the magic?
content: In late May, with most of the world’s best tennis players focused on the red clay at the French Open, Sir Andy Murray was 300 miles away on the other side of the English Channel, dialed in on preparations for the grass at Wimbledon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Jamie Kelter Davis
title: Chicago and NASCAR, an Odd Couple With High Hopes, Take It to the Streets
description: The city and the sport, whose partnership was doubted by many, became acquainted on a soggy weekend downtown. The reviews were mixed.
content: On a rainy holiday weekend, the city of Chicago and the sport of NASCAR celebrated the unlikeliest of marriages with a lakefront ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Russian Forces Launch Overnight Drone Attacks on Kyiv
description: The assault was the first pre-dawn drone barrage to target the Ukrainian capital in almost two weeks, officials said.
content: Russian forces launched a wave of drone attacks on Ukraine’s capital before dawn on Sunday, the first aerial assault on Kyiv by unmanned vehicles in nearly two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Proud Boys Fined Over $1 Million for Destroying Property of a Black Church
description: A judge in Washington, D.C., called the group’s actions, which included tearing down a Black Lives Matter sign, “overtly racist.”
content: A judge in Washington, D.C., on Friday ordered members of the Proud Boys to pay over $1 million to a historic Black church after it sued the far-right group for destruction of property in a December 2020 episode in which the group’s members tore down the church’s large Black Lives Matter sign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wolpe
title: As a Rabbi, I’ve Had a Privileged View of the Human Condition
description: We need religion now more than ever.
content: For over a quarter century now, I have listened to people’s stories, sat by their bedsides as life slipped away, buried their parents, spouses and sometimes their children. Marriages have ended in my office, as have engagements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: A.I. Is Coming for Mathematics, Too
description: For thousands of years, mathematicians have adapted to the latest advances in logic and reasoning. Are they ready for artificial intelligence?
content: In the collection of the Getty museum in Los Angeles is a portrait from the 17th century of the ancient Greek mathematician Euclid: disheveled, holding up sheets of “Elements,” his treatise on geometry, with grimy hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: ‘The Bear’ and a Chaotic Vision of Work
description: The show offers a depiction of work that’s turbulent, and, in its own way, enviable.
content: Business leaders are resorting to desperate measures to entice workers back to the office, my colleague Emma Goldberg reported recently. “It’s been three years of scattershot plans for returning to in-person work — summoning people in, not really meaning it, everybody pretty much working wherever they pleased,” she wrote. “Now, for the umpteenth time, businesses are ready to get serious.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Fireworks for All, One Day Only, in Australia’s Last Frontier
description: In the vast and sparsely populated Northern Territory, residents’ sense of rugged individualism finds expression every July 1, explosively.
content: As fireworks lit up the three-mile stretch of coastline in the capital of Australia’s remote Northern Territory, a swath of grass along the beach went up in flames.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Igoe
title: The Disappearing Act of Literary Translation, in Full View
description: Translators used to be secondary characters in the publishing industry. An issue of The New York Times Book Review aims to put their craft in the spotlight.
content: The art of translation was on Gregory Cowles’s mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: Japan’s Native Ainu Fight to Restore a Last Vestige of Their Identity
description: A group representing the Indigenous people has sued to regain the right, lost over a century ago, to freely fish for salmon in a Hokkaido river.
content: Masaki Sashima gazed through the fog one recent afternoon onto the gray waters of the Tokachi River in Hokkaido, Japan’s northernmost island. From here, his Indigenous people, the Ainu, once used spears and nets to catch the salmon they regarded as gifts from the gods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: If You Don’t Have Anything Nice to Say, Don’t Be a Reference
description: Sometimes maximum awkwardness is worth it, if it means you can be honest.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Jon Haggins, Designer Who Slipped Into and Out of Fashion, Dies at 79
description: He was a member of a cohort of Black designers celebrated in the late 1960s and early ’70s. But struggles with financing led to several changes in direction.
content: Jon Haggins, a fashion designer and bon vivant who found fame in the late 1960s and early ’70s with his sinuous, sensuous designs, but who struggled with financing and shuttered and reopened his business and reinvented himself several times, most recently as the host of a travel show on cable television, died on June 15 at his home in Queens. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Radley Balko
title: Half the Police Force Quit. Crime Dropped.
description: The charming town has a powerful tale to tell.
content: In a staggering report last month, the Department of Justice documented pervasive abuse, illegal use of force, racial bias and systemic dysfunction in the Minneapolis Police Department. City police officers engaged in brutality or made racist comments, even as a department investigator rode along in a patrol car. Complaints about police abuse were often slow-walked or dismissed without investigation. And after George Floyd’s death, instead of ending the policy of racial profiling, the police just buried the evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How a Mentor to At-Risk Young Men Spends His Sundays
description: Toddrick Brockington, who works at the Henry Street Settlement, tends to his mental health and his sneaker collection.
content: Before Toddrick Brockington got his job at the Henry Street Settlement, a nonprofit that supports Lower East Side residents, he served 26 years in prison for homicide. The irreversibility of that act troubles him still. It also keeps him mindful. “I appreciate life more, and when I say that, I don’t mean specifically my life,” he said, “I mean other people’s lives.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiren Lu, Jack D'Isidoro, Elisheba Ittoop, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and David Mason
title: The Sunday Read: ‘A Week With the Wild Children of the A.I. Boom’
description: In Silicon Valley’s hacker houses, the latest crop of young entrepreneurs is partying, innovating — and hoping not to get crushed by the big guys.
content: HF0, or Hacker Fellowship Zero, is a start-up accelerator that provides 12-week residencies for batches of fellows from 10 different start-ups. Their experience, which culminates in a demonstration day, is supposed to be the most productive three months of the fellows’ lives. Dave Fontenot, one of HF0’s founders, was inspired by the two years he spent living in monasteries in his 20s: While monastery life was materially ascetic, he found that it was luxurious in the freedom it gave residents to focus on the things that really mattered. And this year at the Archbishop’s Mansion in San Francisco, the home of the fellows, almost everyone has been monastically focused on what has become the city’s newest religion: artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Kurtis Lee
title: Los Angeles Hotel Workers Go on Strike
description: The strike is part of a wave of recent labor actions in the nation’s second-largest metropolis, where high costs of living have made it difficult for workers to stay afloat.
content: Thousands of hotel workers in Southern California walked off the job on Sunday demanding higher pay and better benefits, just as hordes of tourists descended on the region for the Fourth of July holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Robert Sherman, Veteran of the New York Airwaves, Dies at 90
description: For more than five decades, he brought together emerging classical and folk performers as well as established stars for interviews and live performances.
content: Robert Sherman, a charming, easygoing radio personality who hosted three long-running shows over more than a half-century on the New York classical music station WQXR-FM, died on Tuesday at his home in Ossining, N.Y., in Westchester County. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Fatal Shooting of a Teenager Shocks an Urban Oasis
description: A 15-year-old boy was killed near basketball courts at Riverbank State Park in Harlem, a popular spot for picnics, gardening and swimming.
content: As he often does, Clark Peña was sitting on a bench in Riverbank State Park in Harlem on Saturday evening, catching up on work and watching families play and picnic on a humid Fourth of July weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: The Naming of Gaming (and Its History)
description: The word “gaming” has been used in The Times to refer to gambling, video games and the recent rise of legalized sports betting.
content: On Page 8 of a Saturday issue of The New York Times in 1931 appeared the headline “‘Old West’ Returns in Nevada Gambling.” It announced a historical moment for the state, which, at the time, was the only one with legal casino gambling. “The hum and hubbub of gambling, the click-clack of machines and the clatter of poker chips were partly drowned by the staccato noise of a compressed air drill operated by a construction crew engaged in cutting through massive walls to enlarge the gaming room,” the article read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: ‘American Made’ T-Shirts Are Having Their Best Year Yet
description: Flag-themed apparel and other Americana are always July Fourth favorites, but it now may matter more where those stars and stripes were stitched.
content: When Bayard Winthrop, the chief executive of the retailer American Giant, ordered the batch of shirts that his company would advertise for the Fourth of July, he didn’t think much of it. The retailer, which has been producing its apparel solely in factories around the United States for more than a decade, perennially leans into its “Made in America” pitch for Independence Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Large Crack Spotted in Roller Coaster Prompts Its Shutdown
description: A visitor to the North Carolina amusement park recorded a crack in a pillar of the ride, Fury 325, which is billed as one of the tallest of its kind.
content: A roller coaster at an amusement park in Charlotte, N.C., was shut down on Friday after a visitor spotted a large crack in one of the ride’s pillars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: Uncensored Chatbots Provoke a Fracas Over Free Speech
description: A new generation of chatbots doesn’t have many of the guardrails put in place by companies like Google and OpenAI, presenting new possibilities — and risks.
content: A.I. chatbots have lied about notable figures, pushed partisan messages, spewed misinformation or even advised users on how to commit suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Vivek Shankar
title: Mayors Are Targeted in Fifth Night of Protests Across France
description: Despite a generally calmer evening of demonstrations over the police killing of a 17-year-old, two attacks aimed at civic leaders highlighted the tinderbox situation.
content: The mayor of a suburb of Paris said on Sunday that protesters had rammed a car into his home and then set the vehicle on fire, injuring his wife and one of his children, as violent demonstrations across France over the police killing of a 17-year-old stretched into a fifth night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Biden Is Taking Aim at Trump’s Biggest Strength
description: The administration is thickly populated with veterans of the Obama and Clinton White Houses. But it doesn’t see itself in comfortable continuity with those legacies.
content: Joe Biden just offered a window into what a Biden-Trump rematch might look like. Well, part of it, at least.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 2, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 2, 2023.
content: An article last Sunday about financial planning by L.G.B.T.Q. people mis­stated the year that Yassin Adams arrived in the United States from Egypt. It was 2012, not 2015. The article also misstated the amount he pays for hormone care every three months. It is $500, not $5,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘Urban Explorers’ and Accused Spies Chafe in Legal Limbo in Albania
description: Since their arrest at a derelict arms factory in Albania that they said they were exploring to document in pictures, the two Russians and a Ukrainian have been unable to leave the country.
content: Striking pictures of urban decay, including Soviet-era bomb shelters overgrown with weeds and the crumbling remains of factories across Eastern Europe, won a Russian photographer hundreds of thousands of Instagram followers eager to track her travels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Married to an Art Monster
description: In Charlotte Mendelson’s “The Exhibitionist,” a wife and children live in the shadow of a blustering, egotistic, once important painter.
content: “I prefer stories about squalor,” J.D. Salinger’s Esmé said. Esmé would have gone nuts for “The Exhibitionist,” the fifth novel by the English writer Charlotte Mendelson, which was longlisted for the Women’s Prize for Fiction in 2022. Set in sophisticated if not exactly moneyed quarters of London, with excursions to Edinburgh, it’s a model of tightly controlled domestic chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: No Sparklers for These Folks
description: Whether because of crowds, politics or a loss of patriotism, some Americans are conflicted about celebrating the Fourth of July.
content: Growing up in Benton, Ark., Malaya Tapp loved celebrating the Fourth of July with her family. “We would go to parades and see firework shows and hang out with friends,” she said. “It was always such a fun holiday.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donna Owens and Amanda Holpuch
title: Shooting in Baltimore Leaves 2 Dead and 28 Wounded
description: Frustrated officials sought information from the public about the shooting, which happened early on Sunday at a block party in the city’s southern neighborhood of Brooklyn.
content: Frustrated Baltimore officials pleaded on Sunday with residents to come forward with information about a shooting at a crowded neighborhood block party that left two people dead and 28 others wounded, many of them teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: A Climate Laggard in America’s Industrial Heartland Has a Plan to Change, Fast
description: Lawmakers in Michigan have long fought tough pollution controls. But the toll of flooding, lost crops and damage to the Great Lakes appears to be changing minds.
content: From toxic algal blooms in the Great Lakes to sewage pouring into Detroit basements to choking wildfire smoke that drifted south from Canada, Michigan has been contending with the fallout from climate change. Even the state’s famed cherry trees have been struggling against rising temperatures, forcing some farmers to abandon the crop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Rabin and Lisa Patel
title: Our Childrens’ Lungs Are Uniquely Vulnerable to All This Wildfire Smoke
description: Like the smoke particles that seep into our homes through a window crack, the effects of fossil fuel pollution put nearly every child at risk.
content: When smoke from Canadian wildfires was descending upon parts of the Midwest and Eastern United States in early June, children and parents gathered in the courtyard of Burns Park Elementary in Ann Arbor, Mich., for a picnic celebrating the last week of school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: One Black Family, One Affirmative Action Ruling, and Lots of Thoughts
description: The Supreme Court ruling is just the latest version of a question that the Whitehead family — and the nation — has been grappling with for years: How to deal with the legacy of slavery?
content: For the Whiteheads, an African American family living in the city of Baltimore, race is discussed at the dinner table. In the car on the way to work and school and games. In the backyard while the sons practice sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: As 2024 Voting Battles Heat Up, North Carolina G.O.P. Presses Forward
description: Republicans, whose edge in the state has narrowed in recent years, have gone on offense politically, leading to clashes over voting access and control over elections.
content: A closely watched political fight is developing in North Carolina over voting rights and control of elections, as Democrats aim to recapture a presidential battleground and Republicans look to win back the governor’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Frank Field, Who Brought Expertise to TV Weathercasting, Dies at 100
description: The first meteorologist to forecast the weather on New York television, he later became known for, among other things, publicizing the Heimlich maneuver.
content: Frank Field, who as a meteorologist brought a groundbreaking credential to his job as a television weather forecaster in New York, and who also had a long career presenting network programs on science and medicine, died on Saturday in Florida. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: With End of Affirmative Action, a Push for a New Tool: Adversity Scores
description: To build a diverse class of students, the medical school at U.C. Davis ranks applicants by the disadvantages they have faced. Can it work nationally?
content: For the head of admissions at a medical school, Dr. Mark Henderson is pretty blunt when sizing up the profession.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘On a Whim, I Decided to Do a Silly, Shirley Temple-esque Tap Dance’
description: Waiting for the PATH, leaves fly like birds down Madison Avenue and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Aficionados of TCM Fear for Its Future
description: Responses to Maureen Dowd’s column about Turner Classic Movies. Also: Birth control; the homelessness crisis; a landmark church; cultivated meat.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Yurii Shyvala and David Guttenfelder
title: In Small Victory, Signs of Grueling Combat Ahead in Ukrainian Counteroffensive
description: Expecting a quick retreat, a volunteer Ukrainian unit instead faced two days of tough resistance from dug-in Russian forces.
content: The Ukrainian soldiers thought the Russians would quickly retreat from Neskuchne, a tiny village in southern Ukraine, especially after a concerted artillery barrage and a rocket strike on their headquarters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s Great ‘Indiana Jones’ Adventure
description: “I’m not interested in perfectly behaved men or women,” the actress says. “I’m drawn to the ones who feel a bit dangerous.”
content: “I’m not interested in perfectly behaved men or women,” the actress says. “I’m drawn to the ones who feel a bit dangerous.”
source.name: The New York Times
